results.title: Sunshine [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Istvan Szabo, Andras Hamori, Robert Lantos and Serendipity Point Films
results.brief_description: Sunshine is an epic drama that follows the lives of three generations of Hungarian Jews from the late 18th century to the 19th century. Ralph Fiennes plays three different roles in this film which begins with the Grandfather developing a tonic that becomes the family’s fortune. The family will experience much pain and heartbreak, mostly due to the invasion of the Nazi’s and some family members conversion from Jewish to Catholic - events that could lead to a family’s demise. “Sunshine” shows how determination and courage can unite a family through struggle and ensure the survival of future generations.

results.title: The Godfather. Part III [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Francis Ford Coppola and Zoetrope Studios
results.brief_description: Al Pacino reprises his role as the powerful family patriarch, Michael Corleone. Now in his 60s, Michael is dominated by two passions: freeing his family from their connections with the Mafia and finding a suitable successor. That successor could be his hot-headed, violence-prone nephew, Vincent, played by Andy Garcia, but he may also be the spark that turns Michael’s hopes of business legitimacy into an inferno of mob violence. Stars Diane Keaton as Michael’s long-suffering wife and Sophia Coppola as his wilful daughter, Mary, who is involved in a fiery affair with Vincent. Eli Wallach is one of the old dons of the Corleone family and Joe Mantegna is Michael’s arch-enemy, Joey Zasa. This third film in the epic Corleone trilogy matches it’s predecessors in narrative intensity, socio-political analysis, physical beauty and depth of feeling for its characters. Original music by Carmine Coppola.

results.title: The Godfather. Part II [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Francis Ford Coppola, Coppola Company and Paramount Pictures
results.brief_description: In this sequel to “The Godfather”, set in 1940s-50s, Michael Corleone has taken over his father’s mantle as head of the powerful Mafia family. Director Coppola tells two stories - the roots and rise of a young Don Vito, played by Robert De Niro, and the ascension of Michael Corleone (Al Pacino) as the new Don. Throughout the film, flashback sequences shot in a neorealist style, parallel the two lives of father and son. A complex, epic vision of the corruption of American society, the film is widely considered to be as good as, if not better than the original. It won several Academy Awards including Best Picture, Director, Supporting Actor (DeNiro), Screenplay, Score and Art direction/set decoration and was followed by “The Godfather. Part III” sixteen years later. Original music by Carmine Coppola.

results.title: The Godfather [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Francis Ford Coppola, Albert Ruddy and Paramount Pictures
results.brief_description: Francis Ford Coppola’s epic masterpiece features Oscar winner Marlon Brando as the patriarch of the Corleone family. Coppola paints a chilling portrait of a Sicilian family’s rise and near fall from power in America, and the passage of rites from father to son. He masterfully balances the story between family life and the ugly business of crime in which they are engaged. Based on Mario Puzo’ best selling novel, this graphic and brilliant film garnered ten Academy Award nominations. Cast also includes Al Pacino, James Caan, Robert Duvall, Sterling Hayden and Diane Keaton.

results.title: Dodge City
results.creator_credit: Michael Curtiz and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: Michael Curtiz (Mildred Pierce, Casablanca, Angels with dirty faces) directed this star vehicle for Errol Flynn with whom he collaborated the year before on “The Adventures of Robin Hood”. In “Dodge City” Flynn plays Wade Hatton, a successful and scrupulous man who, with a loyal crew in tow, herds buffalo across Texas to various destinations. On one such trip the crew are also protecting settler families headed for Dodge City. The frontier life is depicted as dangerous and corrupt, especially in towns thriving on alcohol, gambling and prostitution. As a town with no sheriff, Dodge City is such a town - violent, lawless and ruled by the local saloon owner who murders any individual that tries to collect on honest debts. As a principled and fearless man, Hatton is implored to be sheriff and clean up Dodge City. Flynn is well cast as Hatton, a charming and handsome cowboy. Oliva de Havilland (who starred as Maid Marion in The Adventures of Robin Hood) plays his love interest Abbie Irving, a schoolteacher and journalist. As a Western intended for the Saturday matinee “Dodge City” is replete with scenes of cattle stampedes, bar room brawls and runaway trains. “Dodge City” features some glorious exterior scenes and was filmed in Technicolour.

results.title: East is east
results.creator_credit: Damien O'Donnell, Leslee Udwin, Assassin Films and Film Four International
results.brief_description: Set in a small town in the north of England in 1971 this comedy/drama focuses on the inter-generational and cross-cultural conflicts in a large Anglo-Pakistani family. Patriarch George Kahn’s attempts to instill traditional Pakistani values in his seven young adult children are constantly thwarted— both by his easy going British wife and the siblings’ own ambitions. In their claustrophobically cramped terrace house, anarchy erupts daily with farcical energy. The film takes a more serious turn when Kahn decides to set up arranged marriages for his eldest sons. The fierce resistance he faces from his children and their deep resentment at the fact that he has never acknowledged the reality of their lives force him to confront his own chauvinist nature. Cast includes Om Puri and Linda Bassett.

results.title: Tokyo drifter
results.creator_credit: Seijun Suzuki, Tetsuro Nakagawa and Nikkatsu Kabushiki Kaisha
results.brief_description: The Tokyo drifter is Tetsu, a loyal hit man, given to wearing white suits, living out of his time. Tetsu is drawn by his former employer, now attempting to go straight, into a struggle with a rival gang. This is ostensibly a formula genre (yakuza) film transformed by Suzuki into an absurdist thriller by pushing iconography and conventions to hyperbolic extremes. Also pushed to extremes is the characterisation of the nihilistic hero of the yakuza film (a Japanese hero stripped of traditional codes and rituals) played here by a Japanese teenage idol. According to critic Tadao Sato, Suzuki’s farces have roots not only in early Japanese cinema but also in the comical literature of the Edo period (1765-1831). The stylised violence combines humour and aesthetics in the manner of 19th century kabuki ‘blood festivals’. Cast: Tetsuya Watari, Chieko Matsubara, Tamio Kawaji, Hideaki Nitani, Eiji Goh. In Japanese with English subtitles.

results.title: The Graduate (Special edition)
results.creator_credit: Mike Nichols, Lawrence Turman, Embassy Pictures Corporation (US) and Lawrence Turman Inc
results.brief_description: Mentally adrift after graduating from college, Benjamin Braddock is pressured by both family and friends to take on the responsibilities of adulthood, namely to marry and find a job. But the exhortation of family friend, Mr. Robinson, to seize every possible opportunity inspires Ben to accept Mrs. Robinson’s offers of sex. Shortly after, Ben is pushed into dating the Robinsons’ daughter, Elaine, and after falling in love with her he finds himself in the compromising position of maintaining a relationship with both women. Also includes a 45 min. documentary on the making of the film. Cast includes: Dustin Hoffman, Anne Bancroft, Katherine Ross, William Daniels, Elizabeth Wilson and Murray Hamilton.

results.title: Branded to kill [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Seijun Suzuki, Kaneo Iwai and Nikkatsu Kabushiki Kaisha
results.brief_description: Hanado Goro, no. 3 gunman in the Tokyo underworld after killing no. 2 and bungling the fourth of a series of imaginatively executed ‘hits’, finds himself playing cat-and-mouse with the dangerous no. 1. Explosions of violence are punctuated by moments of unexpected lyricism and intermingled with bizarre humour (Hanado is sexually aroused by the smell of boiled rice). After making dozens of run-of-the-mill genre films for Nikkatsu, Sejun Suzuki began transforming the banal material assigned to him into farcically hyperbolic absurdist thrillers reinventing the yakuza film by drawing on Japanese comical literary, theatrical and cinematic traditions (see also “Tokyo drifter”), in the process attracting both a cult following and the ire of Nikkatsu. Cast includes Jo Shishido, Koji Nanbara, Isao Tamagawa, Annu Mari, Mariko Ogawa and Hiroshi Minami. In Japanese with English subtitles.

results.title: Blue murder [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Michael Jenkins, Rod Allan, ABC-TV (Australia), AFFC and Southern Star Entertainment
results.brief_description: Based on the events that led to the Royal Commission on Police Corruption in New South Wales, “Blue Murder” is a rivetting and exceptionally well executed thriller about police corruption and gangland criminal activity in Australia. The convincing script by Ian David focuses on both the intricacies of corruption in the police force, as well as examining the sometimes Byzantine behaviour and “moral” codes of the organised crime world. Richard Roxburgh is outstanding as Roger Rogerson, the larrikin police chief whose egalitarian blokey demeanor allows him to build a lucrative “alternative” career based on bribery, drug money and murder. Tony Martin is Neddy Smith, one of Australia’s most notorious underworld thugs who, by being the conduit between the police and the criminal underworld, is able to build an extensive drug empire in Australia. Rogerson and Smith’s activities are threatened when a young police officer, Michael Drury (Steve Bastoni), declines a bribe offered to him by Rogerson. From that moment on, “Blue Murder” depicts how Drury’s involvement in acting as an informer on Rogerson’s activities led to increasing desperate and murderous acts by both police and crims. Acclaimed internationally as a landmark television mini-series, “Blue Murder” was for years unable to be screened in NSW or available for view on video in Australia due to elements of the story being seen as prejudicial to legal trials in NSW and Federal Courts. Apart from the leads, the mini-series features excellent performances by Alex Dimitriades, Peter Phelps and John Hargreaves.

The convincing script by Ian David focuses on both the intricacies of corruption in the police force, as well as examining the sometimes Byzantine behaviour and “moral” codes of the organised crime world. Richard Roxburgh is outstanding as Roger Rogerson, the larrikin police chief whose egalitarian blokey demeanor allows him to build a lucrative “alternative” career based on bribery, drug money and murder. Tony Martin is Neddy Smith, one of Australia’s most notorious underworld thugs who, by being the conduit between the police and the criminal underworld, is able to build an extensive drug empire in Australia. Rogerson and Smith’s activities are threatened when a young police officer, Michael Drury (Steve Bastoni), declines a bribe offered to him by Rogerson. From that moment on, “Blue Murder” depicts how Drury’s involvement in acting as an informer on Rogerson’s activities led to increasing desperate and murderous acts by both police and crims. Acclaimed internationally as a landmark television mini-series, “Blue Murder” was for years unable to be screened in NSW or available for view on video in Australia due to elements of the story being seen as prejudicial to legal trials in NSW and Federal Courts. Apart from the leads, the mini-series features excellent performances by Alex Dimitriades, Peter Phelps and John Hargreaves.
